author: otaviolima
title: ADA Scam Alert - Info & Protection
description: Where to find reliable, secure and credible information about the trust, professionalism, technique and seriousness of blockchain projects.

f6_assessments.q0:
While Cardano technology needs scaling, this looks more like an incorrectly described entrant for this category.
It is described like WebUI app, where main problems seem to be how to implement trust checking, assure transparency, expose fraud, assure security. It would be better to devote at least one paragraph to how each pillar will be implemented, instead of enumerating them.

It seems also unclear how the network in the project description suffices to prevent scam. The project participants seem to conscpicuously lack experience in scam prevention, fraud prevention, market surveillance, and law. All these components become important, as exposing any fraud requires in-depth knowledge, and involves legal risks.

Scam prevention is complex issue that requires due dilligence, verifiability and communication with the partners. None of these topics are even raised in the project description.

Of these three, it seems that only the last aspect is anyhow touched.

As a CA I would like to see more detail of how the scam-prevention and protection would be realized. What specialist skills do project participants have that allow tackling this specific problem.

The current stage of the proposal suggests that authors have identified the need for anti-scam protection, but did not detail any options to tackle them.

Since anti-scam protection is similarly hard problem as anti-spam protection, it is quite conceivable that it will be very difficult to address without a comprehensive plan, and many options.

In case of these options, it would be nice to see that the proposed solutions are feasible and cost-effective.
f6_assessments.q1:
It is unclear how the platform would address issues of fairness, and defamation lawsuits.

Verification of the website visits (using: https://www.similarweb.com/website/cardanofeed.com/#overview) suggests that there are 0.5M visitors, but they 3/4 of them bounce, leading to a very short visit time (about 1.5mins).

This suggests that the website given as an example is having rather low retention.

Since the project describes implementation of a generic web  app, it is unclear whether the initial goals would be satisfied.
f6_assessments.q2:
KPIs are clearly described, as is the project plan.

However, the user retention and bounce rate are disregarded. This suggests that a website that captures accidental traffic would also satisfy the KPI.

KPIs are somewhat disconnected from the project goals. The goals are to increase trustworthiness of Cardano projects, but the KPIs only talk about increasing web site user base.

It should be explained why the real goals of the project are disconnected from the KPIs, or other KPIs should be added.

f6_assessments.q0:
The Challenge Brief is seeking scaling solutions for the Cardano blockchain. It specifically mentions extensions to Hydra, porting over solutions in other blockchains and has specific scalability topic areas of: Rollups, Sharding, Sidechains, and State Channels.
____________________________________________________
The proposal as I read it is a Risk Management proposal for assessing Projects. It does not appear to take into account any of the Challenge briefs metrics. The solution summary is for a Platform to classify, analyze and rank projects for fraud, security and reliability in project verification.
___________________________________________________
I would suggest this proposal, which appears to have strength and depth would be  better suited in: Improve and Grow Auditability or perhaps even Dapps and Integrations.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal does not solve the issue of the Challenge brief. It does address the problem stated in the proposal and does appear that it may solve that issue. I think on it's own, in the correct Challenge setting, with the technical expertise and experience of the proposing team this could be a solid project. My suggestion for the team would be to detail the budget a little more and do a full SWOT. Please make certain the problem(s) in the Challenge Brief is what your Proposal is addressing.
f6_assessments.q2:
The project lists four (4) progress metrics to be measured. All four state the measurement will be "Number of...", yet there are no quantitative metrics. I would suggest that to measure, monitor and change course midstream a target would be essential. The second measurement stated is " Number of registered projects", to which my advice would that you need a number with projected revenue or other metric to let the community understand if your are on course. This would be the same for your other three metrics:
How many website hits?,
How many page hits? 
How many shares on social networks?
___________________________________________________
It is my suggestion to quantify your metrics and polish your KPIs' for your proposal to have a more solid auditability basis. Voters may require this for your proposal to be considered for up-voting.

f6_assessments.q0: I like this idea! I would like to see a more thorough proposal about it but this is a good idea. An objective standardized criteria of how projects rank compared to one another could be a tremendously helpful tool for the community to better determine where they want to put their money. I could see some risk of deeper developed tribalism within the Cardano community but I still think this would be a great tool. I do want more specifics on how each criterion is evaluated and I think the current list could be expanded more as well (with something like community engagement measured by social media following and activity). I think it would be relevant information to also provide some market research about how many developing projects are coming up on Cardano, how many people are following new Cardano projects, how much money people spend on altcoins, how many scams happen per year, and other information that demonstrates the need for this type of product. These might be sort of above and beyond type details, which is why I still vote positive. Just don't actually call it ADA Scam Alert.
f6_assessments.q1: Stock issues are roadmap and dev team. This project provides a detailed roadmap on what different things will be done and worked on in a 6-month period of time, which sounds perfectly reasonable to me. Then, the resume of the team looks perfectly capable of accomplishing what's listed here AND the resume of the team is verifiable with links to each member's LinkedIn profile. This one's a winner on feasibility. The budget looks nice too. The developers are hardly in anything at $16/hr, if you assume 40 hours a week. I generally only look for overpaid labor (which there is none of here), so underpaid labor gets a positive (though comes with a bit of judgment). This feasibility section is perfect.
f6_assessments.q2: I think they let themselves off too easy on this section. I do think the given criteria are the right areas to be paying attention to but there's no point in just watching the numbers if there are no specific goals for it. They also provide no resources for public accountability, which is a requirement for me in any request over $20k. Committing to updates on social media, websites, or to a trusted 3rd party produces trust. I give bonus points for proposals that give specific milestone-based metrics that increase over time. This section is lacking for a $45k proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: Nowhere in the proposal does it mention scalability solutions and thus misses the challenge's purpose.
f6_assessments.q1: Their "Full stack and software engineer" lists Harvard on his LinkedIn. The CS50 course, however, is commonly taken through HarvardX / EdX. f6_assessments.q0: Unfortunately, it seems that the team behind this proposal has not aligned the proposal well with the correct challenge. This challenge [Cardano Scaling Solutions] is aimed at technical scaling solutions for transactions on the Cardano blockchain with four specific scalability topic areas [Rollups (e.g. zero knowledge rollups, optimistic rollups), Sharding, Sidechains and State channels]. The proposal in question is for deverloping a platform to classify, analyze and rank projects being developed on/for Cardano. As such, the key metrics and goals of the proposal do not align well with the outlined challenge settings. I would recommend that the team resubmit the proposal to a better challenge in Fund 9, if it is not approved. In this Fund it would probably be a better fit in the F8: Miscellaneous Challenge.
f6_assessments.q1: The feasibility seems relatively straightforward based on the team's competencies (they included links to their Linkedin profiles). They have developed a Cardanofeed.com news aggregator that offers Cardano related news that seems automatically curated. The site is functional although a bit underwhelming. The team has provided a budget and a budget breakdown. The plan is for running the project 12 months based on this segment of the budget [Amazon AWS Services Maintenance (1 year) = $1,600]. I would have liked to see a plan for making the project self-sustaining after the 12 month period expires. Not sure if the team thought about the project's longevity, if yes - it would be good to include details if the proposal is resubmitted. One important aspect about the feasibility relates to the professed goal of "We will seek all available ways to carry out a complete analysis of the project, going through several analysis pillars such as: Technique, Security, Fraud, Fundamentals, Technical Team, Transparency, Trust". Each of these pillars is a major endeavour and the proposal does not include details on how will this be done, nor does the budget include information on experts for these segments. The team has not indicated how many projects will be analyzed and how projects will be selected and related details.
f6_assessments.q2: The team proposes relatively general metrics for auditability. The auditability is based on number of hits to the website - however what is the aim? A thousand hits or a million? The number of registered projects is also unclear, as there is no specific mention of project registration or selection method in the proposal... Etc... The targets seem too generic and do not correspond in my view well to the professed aim "we will analyze and classify, we include a technical analysis of the project, in addition to code security, potential risks, signs of fraud, bringing more reliability to invest in the project." Numbers of shares, views - are probably less relevant than number of projects that have been checked in-depth and number of detections of code insecurity, risks, signs of fraud...etc...Without a budget - or revenue generating mechanism - I am not sure how will the project scale to address future challenges.The metrics and KPIs could be better aligned with the problem statement/solution. THe milestones seem deliverable, but not comprehensive enough to include everything that the project wishes to deliver. I am not sure who will be conducting the audit and certification of source code; fraud and security analysis as this is not in the budget breakdown. I mention this as the proposal aims to deliver a platform to classify, analyze and rank projects according to risk management, fraud, security and reliability in project verification.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal contains four members' massive profile information that covers around 404 or ~50% out of 918 words of the entire proposal written. The auditability part has only 51 words explaining how the project would be ordered in six months for the proposal request of $45,600. 

In terms of wording length, there's nothing wrong with the Fund 8 proposal guidelines. However, the proposal should at least underline and make no ubiquitous whether the proposal will depend on and use the data input from cardanofeed.com or not and for the reader if these data will be feeding to the following analysis or not: Technique, Security, Fraud, Fundamentals, Technical Team, Transparency, Trust.

With the proposal title "ADA Scam alert - Info & Protection", I expect the impact would be delivered somehow to the end-users or devices. It alerts the user using some top of communication medium instead of visiting cardanofeed.com. The proposal's impact has not provided any of those at all, and yet not to mention how this information is being verified and the source. 

I will give 4 if there are some signs, how-to or methods in written on how the data will "classify, analyze and rank" to support your proposal, or therefore I rate 3 out of 5 for the impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
The feasibility has been listed for six months of the entire project timeline. It's pretty detailed for eight months what they are going to achieve. However, there is no clarity on whether this feasibility has any link with the information provided in the impact part and the proposal statement.

If not read the last question of the auditability about whether this project is new or not, then impact and feasibility would be very confusing. The most confusing part is if the team is going to build an entirely new project, it has nothing to do with cardanofeed.com, then the statement had to make very clear for whoever is involved in reading this project. 
Finally, the feasibility of milestones should correlate with impact to starting with. For that, I rate the feasibility for this proposal is 3 out of 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
Apart from 51 words in audibility part is "Number of hits to the website". From my limited understanding of cyber security and with this phrase meaning, I believe that the BOT or some type of automated scripts can randomize and send from different IP addresses with IP spoofing technique and interval to the sensor or collection database to create a significant hit from various sources or public IP addresses. 

The same methods can apply to "Number of page hits". Therefore, two out of four of "you will measure the progress and the development of the project" are not that useful to audit. 

In terms of logical writing, challenge team or community does not confuse the readers. The information within the proposal should be clicked together. For instance, in feasibility written "Official launch of the Site" in month sixth, then how the challenge team and IO will report and audit before your project ending and that will be the last release of your funding as well. Possible change the feasibility to match with audibility where can be delivered in 6 months (if keep the same timeline) and underline elements that within release fund period from IO, challenge team or community can audit your working progress.

If you ever do again, I believe your team may consider using Cardano wallet address or NFT-styles to clarify, verify and deliver to end-user access alert. That would be a great idea in the future. With your team experience listed, I believe you would be able to deliver its solution one day.
For these reasons, I rate 1 out of 5 for the audibility of this proposal.
